column16: â€ NDP national director Robert Fox wrote to Graff in a letter submitted to court. The letter also describes Graff as having a â€œpropensity for litigation.â€ Graff
column18: believes the real reason heâ€™s been rejected is that his views donâ€™t align with NDP values. In particular
column19: Graff wants to cut immigration and tie it to the unemployment rate. Foxâ€™s letter does claim that Graffâ€™s beliefs â€œrun counter to the partyâ€™s principles.â€ It also quotes from a 2007 letter from Graff published in Toronto alt-weekly NOW Magazine

column1: capndanvers 160729147760 "2017-05-16 12:00:20 GMT" https://capndanvers.tumblr.com/post/160729147760/the-unbearable-whiteness-of-being-oblivious-to "allthecanadianpolitics:  Canadian media and arts communities were embroiled in controversy this past week
column2: following a spectacularly tone-deaf decision by the editor of Write
column3: the magazine of The Writersâ€™ Union of Canada
column4: to pen an opinion piece titled â€œWinning the Appropriation Prizeâ€ in an issue devoted to Indigenous writing. In the piece
column5: Hal Niedzviecki stated that he doesnâ€™t believe in cultural appropriation and encouraged writers to â€œimagine other peoples
column6: other cultures
column7: other identitiesâ€ as a solution to the undeniable fact that Canadian literature is overwhelmingly dominated by â€œpeople who are white and middle-class.â€ Itâ€™s akin to someone cooking and exclaiming
column8: â€œThis soup contains way too much salt! Iâ€™m now going to solve this problem by adding more salt.â€ A four-year-old could tell you that wouldnâ€™t work. The idea that lack of diversity can be solved by having white writers who benefit from a system of privilege simply appropriate the voices and stories of the marginalized
column9: instead of making genuine room for the excluded
column12: an unavoidable symptom of being part of an elite group for whom the term â€œwhite saviourâ€ was coined. Niedzviecki triumphantly ended his editorial with â€œSet your sights on the big goal: Win the Appropriation Prize.â€ His proposal
column13: justifiably met with disbelief and outrage
column14: prompted Cherokee-born writer Daniel Heath Justice to refer to it as â€œsettler ventriloquism.â€ Faced with considerable backlash
column16: and the Writersâ€™ Union apologized. But itâ€™s what came next that really took this controversy to another and much uglier level. Clearly upset that one of their own had been vilified and hankering to jump in and defend what they thought was truly at stake here â€” free speech â€” prominent members of mainstream media started pledging money for an Appropriation Prize. column1: capndanvers 160092076712 "2017-04-28 19:00:22 GMT" https://capndanvers.tumblr.com/post/160092076712/if-it-doesnt-have-an-hea-or-hfn-its-not "romancingthebookworm:  thebibliosphere:  romancingthebookworm:  I know weâ€™ve seen this discussion pop up more than once (like the author of this piece points out
column2: it usually cycles through every few months) but this is probably one of my favorite set-downs of the Non-HEA crowd yet.Â  Itâ€™s well phrased
column3: fairly comprehensive
column4: and just slightly scathing.  Itâ€™s the utter bane of my existence when people send me their manuscripts to edit
column5: and I get a cover email that read along the lines of â€œIâ€™m not a fan of romance novels so I added my own twistâ€ and my soul curdles because first of all a) if you donâ€™t like romance but youâ€™re writing it because youâ€™ve realized itâ€™s lucrative and you think Anyone can do it because itâ€™s â€œeasyâ€: get the Hell out of my genre and b) suffering and misery instead of a happily ever after (or happy for now) are not twists. Itâ€™s not edgy
column6: itâ€™s not clever
column7: in fact what it shows me is that you do not understand the genre on a fundamental level and shouldnâ€™t be writing for it. Romance is a fantasy genre
column8: people donâ€™t read fantasy for endless suffering (thank you GRRMartin et al for making every edgelord in the world think nitty gritty detail = pain and suffering without relief and flooding the genre with their shitty reimaginings of the characters from Lord of the Rings but set to the plot of SAW) they read fantasy to know that the suffering  will end. That evil will eventually be defeated
column9: that good things can and will still happen and that the sun will shine again. Romance is no different from that
column10: except it is a genre primarily considered to be feminine and therefore subject to ridicule and the belief that somehow if a woman can do it
column11: it must be easy â€œBut Joy
column12: â€ I hear some of you say

column16: whether itâ€™s goofball sci-fi or Lord of the â€œall my characters are white because of historical accuracyâ€ Rings 94949392.0 (or if you really want to start a fight
column17: every mediocre white man considered a classic by the literary genre and lauded by academia for writing about wanting to have an affair with one of his students/the inevitability of death) and while they are subject to criticism
column18: thereâ€™s still not quite the same vitriol that Romance gets for wanting
column20: a happy life. There is nothing wrong with feel good media
column21: there is nothing wrong with wanting to enjoy something a little bit silly and unapologetically happy. The popularity of coffee shop Aus in fandom is both unsurprising and nothing new. Itâ€™s quite literally common romance tropes that have been around forever but with the diversity of fandom (*eyes ao3 tag* kind of) and I will die on this hill defending the validity of Happily Ever Afters and Happily For Now before I let anyone try to take it from my icy cold grip. And if I get one more romance manuscript with a cover letter that says theyâ€™ve added a twist
column22: then god dam y'all someone had better have twisted their ankle and been carried bridal style to their bed because Iâ€™m so over people hating on the simple want for happiness.   This commentary is the best commentary. Everyone else go home.  â€¦ no really. Please.
